review_title: One of the Pathetic Companies in India
pros:
Well, since there are none, I'll just add more cons here
You won't get a decent free coffee. Bonus are non existant and they brag about certifications, other companies have much better certifications.
cons:
The workload is very high, and the people hired for the job are less. 
You will work on weekends and they will give you comp off but the funny thing is those comp off will get expired and you won't even be able to take your privilege leaves. They will literally make you finish work under such pressure and in the name of appreciation the manager will just send you a text message appreciating your work. Forget salary increment- It doesn't happen in IBM, I have been in this company for 5 years and I am good at what I do and yet they just don't give you hike, every 10 months your manager will change and the new manager won't do anything about your hike. So, please do not waste your time joining this company like I did.

pros: There were some good training classes not specific to my job.

I know a lot of IBM employees in multiple markets and I don't know one person who likes working for them.

review_title: Too big to fail? Not really...
pros:
If you're a permanent role:
13.5 months of salary
discretionary bonus
tax-advantaged Housing allowance
pretty good medical insurance (AIA)

If you're a contractor:
10% gratuity upon contract-end

For both perm and contractors (your manager could disapprove any of the following reimbursements if they want to chase the revenue KPI):
support allowance (you still have to support even if you're not eligible to claim for this allowance)
capped mobile service plan reimbursement (bring the laptop assigned to you and have tethering ready when you're "off-work" or on vocation)
capped taxi reimbursement (only applies to receipts after 22:00)
cons:
There's a reason IBM changed the slogan from "Work-life balance" to "Work-life integration" a few years ago. Consider you've given up your work-life balance the day you accepted the offer: 
Depending on your role, you are overloaded with 300%-500% workload.
Unpaid overtime work is normal, you would be working at least 10 hours a day (excluding the lunch break), and depending on your project, you might be required to provide 24x7 production/BAU support parallel with your normal working hours. That means your supposedly after-work life would be frequently disturbed by sms + whatsapp + phone calls, no matter you are sleeping, on sick leave, on annual leave, or on compassionate leave. 

There is nothing tech about IBM, the management (from Band 8 Project Managers to CEO) are all revenue-driven, tech & innovation are not the concerns as long as their accounts' revenue meet the KPI. That means as long as mainframe and other legacy tech is still generating income, they would love to assign resources into that. That's what you got when the management & decision makers are all non-tech person. They are more like salespersons.

job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Markham, ON
pros: IBM is a technical community made with intelligent, smart and hardworking individuals. My team and leadership supports, motivate and encourage us to learn and grow in every possible way. Opportunities are endless at IBM. It really depends on individual to take the opportunities if they want to grow their career and learn new technologies, process etc. IBM seems to have making bold bets and the teams are very flexible in adopting changes so easily nowadays.
cons:
IBM has shrink down on the middle management significantly making the organization more of flat hierarchy. This is a great move and make the organization very agile and flexible to change. Old IBM with bureaucracy and Red tape is long gone. 
However, the change may have added pressure on mid and senior level execs, as a result IBM's overall corporate strategy and vision may not be translated to regular front end workers, leading to misunderstandings.

review_title: Great company to work for mostly
job_title: Software Client Leader in Chicago, IL
pros:
Rate of starting base and commission is very good, especially for younger people starting out. IBM invests 6 months of sales training into all new sales employees, which is invaluable. There is definitely a culture of learning. You can do a multitude of different roles in the company and it is fairly easy to change roles. The company changes and restructures a lot which can be good or bad. You can be located in any major city in the world and it is fairly easy to switch location. 
Typical IBM sales roles require at least 50% travel, which can be good if you like to travel.
cons: The company is extremely large, bureaucratic, and confusing to navigate. It is the epitome of a vertical company, which causes it to be slower than flatter companies. The company is hard to navigate if you’re looking to move up because the progression path from sales roles is not always clear.

review_title: One of the best IT companies to learn and grow
pros: Strong customer footprint, deep technology experience within the company with Cloud, Software, Services, end to end possibilities. World class research on AI, Quantum, Cloud, ... Gives space to learn on IT, Consulting, Sales, Legal, Management... with the big picture view.
cons: IBM is a worldwide leader on many topics, but relies on outdated (crashing) tools like Notes / Verse. The internal process can be bureaucratic and sometimes prevents from focusing on clients and innovation.

review_title: Great on paper, often doesn't live up to its values
job_title: Software Developer in New York, NY
pros: Lots of resources (training, certificates, internal dev/design communities, etc). Decent insurance and benefits (depends on place of work). Flexible work schedule and WFH (depends on team). Emphasis on diversity and inclusion. Never an unreasonable amount of work, even during crunch times. Frequent periods of less-intense work (not on purpose—usually because of administrative overhead/blockers, but it gives employees time to take a breather).
cons: Big "meeting culture" despite the potential for most meetings to be more effectively handled via slack or email. Experience highly dependent on how your immediate manager or squad lead treats you—though frequent structural changes mean you probably won't be on the same team for more than 2 years. Below industry standard salary for tech talent at a company its size. Big and slow bureaucratic structure that treats employees like numbers and stifles growth (the right manager can insulate you from this, but it's impossible to avoid altogether).
